# Summary of Article: Nepali Congress, CPN-UML become winners in Nepal's National Assembly polls

**Key Facts and Statistics:**

- **National Assembly Election Results (held Sunday, Jan. 25, 2026):**
  - Nepali Congress: won 9 seats
  - CPN-UML: won 8 seats
  - Loktantrik Samajwadi Party-Nepal (Democratic Socialist Party-Nepal): won 1 seat
  - Nepali Communist Party: won 0 seats

- **Electoral Context:**
  - About one-third of National Assembly seats fall vacant every two years
  - 19 seats were falling vacant on March 4, 2026
  - Elections were held for 17 seats (one candidate elected unopposed)
  - President Ram Chandra Poudel will nominate one member on government recommendation

- **Current National Assembly Composition (59-member upper house):**
  - Nepali Congress: 25 seats (largest party)
  - Nepali Communist Party: second largest (specific number not stated)
  - CPN-UML: third largest (specific number not stated)

**Notable Information:**

- The Nepali Congress and CPN-UML had formed an alliance for this election
- The Nepali Communist Party (formed after merger of several communist parties including CPN (Maoist Center)) failed to win any seats in this election

**Note:** This article reports on National Assembly (upper house) elections, not House of Representatives (lower house) elections. The forecasting question concerns the 2026 House of Representatives election.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://english.nepalnews.com/s/explainers/all-eyes-on-jhapa-5-who-will-win-balen-or-oli/">
# Summary of Article: "All eyes on Jhapa-5: Who will win – Balen or Oli?"

**Source:** Nepal News  
**Author:** Akhilesh Tripathi

## Key Facts and Statistics:

- **Election Date:** The House of Representatives elections are scheduled for March 5, 2026.
- **Total Constituencies:** 165 electoral constituencies across Nepal.
- **Jhapa-5 Constituency:** A traditional stronghold of the CPN (UML), historically dominated by KP Sharma Oli.
- **2022 Election Results in Jhapa-5:** KP Oli secured more than 52,000 votes, defeating his nearest rival from Nepali Congress by over 28,000 votes.
- **Oli's Electoral History:** Oli has been sent to parliament from Jhapa district several times since the 1991 parliamentary election, often by landslide margins.

## Key Electoral Matchup:

The article focuses on the high-profile contest in Jhapa-5 between:
- **KP Sharma Oli** (CPN-UML Chairman, four-time prime minister) - the incumbent and traditional dominant force in this constituency
- **Balendra Shah (Balen)** (Rastriya Swatantra Party senior leader, former Kathmandu Metropolitan City mayor) - representing what the article describes as "new, emerging political forces"

## Strategic Context:

- **Balen's Decision:** Many political observers were surprised by Balen's choice to contest from Jhapa-5 rather than a Kathmandu constituency where his urban popularity would give him a "comparatively much easier" path to victory.
- **Symbolism:** The article characterizes Balen's move as both a challenge and symbolic gesture - attempting to break the "stranglehold of the long-dominant political force" by challenging Oli in his own backyard.
- **Personal Dynamics:** The relationship between Oli and Balen reportedly "turned sour" after Balen won the Kathmandu mayoral election against UML's Keshav Sthapit. Balen subsequently became "a vocal critic of Oli's style of governance," pointing to "instances of corruption and inefficiency where Oli and the UML were linked."

## Campaign Approaches:

- **Balen's Strategy:** Mass rallies, personal outreach, direct engagement with youth voters, establishing local offices, and attempting to engage "disaffected youth leaders from other parties" to consolidate a broader reformist vote base.
- **Oli's Strategy:** Relying on experience, legacy, and development achievements; campaigning on infrastructure, urban planning, and economic policy accomplishments; mobilizing traditional party loyalists through UML's organizational strength.

## Stakes and Implications:

According to political analysts cited in the article:
- **For Oli:** A loss would weaken the UML's legacy and question the perception of Oli's "invincibility as a political force." The constituency is monitored as "a bellwether of the party's fortune nationally."
- **For Balen:** Victory would "catapult him onto the national stage" and demonstrate that RSP can compete with established parties. It would signal that "a new generation of political leaders with their roots in reformist agendas and experience in urban governance can make their presence felt even in the traditional remote strongholds."

## Broader Electoral Context:

The article characterizes the 2026 elections as "a fight between the so-called old, entrenched political class and the so-called new, emerging political forces," with Jhapa-5 representing the "most strongly" reflected example of this dynamic across all 165 constituencies.

**Note:** The article text appears to be cut off at the end mid-sentence.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://kathmandupost.com/national/2026/01/25/national-assembly-polls-begin-across-provinces">
# Summary of Kathmandupost Article on National Assembly Polls

## Key Facts:

**Election Details:**
- Voting underway on Sunday to elect 17 members of the National Assembly
- Terms of 19 members set to expire on March 4
- Of the 19 vacant seats: 1 member from Koshi Province elected unopposed, 1 to be nominated by the President, and 17 being contested
- Constitutional requirement: elections must be held at least 35 days before seats fall vacant (Article 86(3))
- Voting hours: 9 am to 3 pm, with counting to begin immediately after

**Voter Eligibility and Numbers:**
- Eligible voters: provincial assembly members, mayors, chairpersons, deputy mayors, and vice-chairpersons of local units
- Total voters: 2,056 (including 550 provincial assembly members and 753 local-level chiefs and deputies)
- 14 positions already vacant due to various reasons
- 16 provincial assembly members and 11 local-level officials resigned to contest the upcoming House of Representatives election, making them ineligible to vote
- Final voters' list: 545 provincial assembly members and 1,497 local-unit chiefs and deputies
- Vote weightage: Provincial assembly members = 53; local-unit officials = 19

**Electoral Alliance:**
- Nepali Congress, CPN-UML, and Janata Samajbadi Party-Nepal formed an electoral alliance
- Under the alliance: Congress fielded candidates for 9 seats, UML for 8 seats, JSP-Nepal for 1 seat
- The Nepali Communist Party fielded candidates for all 17 contested seats
- Total candidates in the fray: 43

**Province-by-Province Breakdown:**
The article provides detailed candidate information for all seven provinces (Koshi, Madhesh, Bagmati, Gandaki, Lumbini, Karnali, and Sudurpaschim), listing specific candidates competing in various categories (women, Dalit, persons with disabilities or minorities, and other).

**Relevance to House of Representatives Question:**
This National Assembly election demonstrates current political alignments ahead of the 2026 House of Representatives election, notably the electoral alliance between Nepali Congress, CPN-UML, and JSP-Nepal opposing the newly formed Nepali Communist Party.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/south-asia/national-assembly-polls-nepali-congress-leads-with-9-seat-win-in-upper-house-elections/articleshow/127487799.cms">
# Summary of Article: National Assembly polls in Nepal (January 25, 2026)

## Key Facts and Statistics:

**Election Results:**
- Nepali Congress won 9 seats (most of any party in this election)
- CPN-UML won 8 seats
- Lokatantrik Samajwadi Party won 1 seat
- Elections held for 17 of 18 vacant seats (one candidate elected uncontested)
- Voter turnout: 95.68%
- Voting conducted peacefully from 9 am to 3 pm local time on Sunday

**Current National Assembly Composition (after these results):**
- Total seats: 59 members
- Nepali Congress: 25 seats (largest party in Upper House)
- Nepali Communist Party: 18 seats (second largest)
- CPN-UML: 11 seats (increased from previous strength)
- 56 seats are elected (8 from each of Nepal's 7 provinces)
- 3 seats are nominated by the President

**Electoral System Details:**
- One-third of National Assembly seats become vacant every two years
- Eligible voters include: members of provincial assemblies, mayors, deputy mayors, chairpersons and vice-chairpersons of rural municipalities
- Votes carry different weightage (specific weightage not detailed)

**Political Context:**
- Pre-poll understanding reached between Nepali Congress and CPN-UML ahead of voting

**Source Attribution:** Election Commission (EC) spokesperson Narayan Prasad Bhattarai confirmed peaceful conduct of elections
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://english.nepalnews.com/s/explainers/everything-you-need-to-know-about-nepals-election-history/">
# Summary of "Everything you need to know about Nepal's election history"

**Source:** Nepal News  
**Context:** Article provides historical background on Nepal's electoral history leading up to the March 5, 2026 election.

## Key Facts and Statistics:

### 2026 Election Context:
- **Election date:** March 5, 2026
- **Circumstances:** Following the September 8-9, 2025 Gen Z protest that toppled the elected government, an interim government led by former Chief Justice Sushila Karki dissolved the House of Representatives and announced fresh elections
- This will be the eighth election under multiparty democracy, or ninth in broader parliamentary history

### 2022 General Election Results:
- **Date:** November 20, 2022
- **Participants:** 57 political parties filed nomination papers
- **Outcome:** Hung parliament with no single party securing outright majority
- **Seat distribution:**
  - Nepali Congress: 89 seats (largest party)
  - CPN (UML): 78 seats
  - CPN (Maoist Centre): 32 seats
  - Rashtriya Swatantra Party: 20 seats (strong debut)
  - Rastriya Prajatantra Party: 14 seats
  - Janata Samajwadi Party: 12 seats
  - CPN (Unified Socialist): 10 seats
  - Janamat Party: 6 seats
  - Loktantrik Samajwadi Party, Nepal: 4 seats

### 2017 General Election Results:
- **System:** Mixed electoral system (165 FPTP + 110 PR seats)
- **Participants:** 55 parties in FPTP, 49 in PR
- **Seat distribution:**
  - CPN (UML): 121 seats (largest party)
  - Nepali Congress: 63 seats
  - Maoist party: 52 seats
- **Post-election:** UML and Maoist party merged to form Nepal Communist Party (NCP); KP Sharma Oli became Prime Minister
- **Total representation:** 10 political parties

### Historical Elections (Brief mentions):
- **2013 Constituent Assembly:** Nepali Congress won 196 seats, CPN (UML) 179 seats, Maoist party 80 seats; successfully promulgated Constitution in September 2015
- **2008 Constituent Assembly:** Unified Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist) won 226 seats (later 240); Pushpa Kamal Dahal became PM; failed to complete constitution
- **1999:** Nepali Congress won 111 seats, CPN (UML) 71 seats; 12 women elected
- **1991:** Nepali Congress won 110 seats, CPN (UML) 69 seats

## Expert Opinion:
- Unnamed experts note that while the 2026 election poses significant challenges, it also presents an opportunity, underscoring the continuing evolution of Nepal's electoral and democratic landscape

**Note:** The article text appears to be cut off at the end during the 1994 midterm election section.
</Summary>

# Summary of Al Jazeera Article on 2026 Elections

**Article Overview:** This is a global survey of major elections scheduled for 2026, covering more than 40 countries representing 1.6 billion people.

## Key Information on Nepal's 2026 Election:

**Context and Background:**
- Nepal's upcoming elections were triggered by September 2025 Gen Z-led protests that toppled Prime Minister KP Sharma Oli
- The protests were driven by corruption concerns and economic frustration

**Youth Political Engagement:**
- Many protesters have been campaigning for voter registration
- The article characterizes this as giving Nepalese youth "a real chance to turn their movement into political influence and help shape the country's future"

**Note:** This article provides limited specific details about Nepal's election beyond the general context. The piece is a broad overview of multiple global elections rather than an in-depth analysis of any single contest. The Nepal section is brief and focuses primarily on the youth protest movement's role in precipitating the election and potential ongoing political engagement.
</Summary>

**ECPA Confident of Becoming Leading Party, Vows Easy Victory in Jhapa-5: Yogesh Bhattarai**
Nepali Congress (Unified Marxist–Leninist) Deputy General Secretary Yogesh Bhattarai stated that the party is confident of becoming the leading party in the upcoming elections, emphasizing their strong grassroots connection and historical legacy in Jhapa-5. He noted that party leader KP Sharma Oli has consistently won in Jhapa-5 and has implemented significant development projects there, fostering a deep bond with the local population. Bhattarai asserted that the party's confidence in winning Jhapa-5 easily is rooted in its long-standing relationship with the people and its proven track record of leadership and development in the region. The statement was made during an interview with media on February 1, 2026, in Kathmandu.

**Parbat's Rural Election Campaigns Intensify Ahead of Parliamentary Polls**
The upcoming parliamentary election in Nepal, scheduled for Falgun 21, 2081 (March 5, 2025), is approaching, intensifying political activity in rural Parbat district. Thirteen political parties have fielded candidates in the district, with key contenders including Arjun Prasad Joshi (Nepali Congress), Padam Giri (Communist Party of Nepal - Unified Marxist–Leninist, UML), Manhari Sharma (Nepali Communist Party), and Sagar Bhusal (Rastriya Swatantra Party). Candidates are actively engaging with voters at the village level, presenting their platforms and policy proposals. Voters are raising concerns about national issues such as unemployment, corruption, and poor governance, as well as local priorities including road development, quality healthcare, irrigation, job creation, and monkey menace control. While most villages in Parbat’s seven municipalities have access to blacktopped roads, residents are demanding higher-quality roads extending to individual hamlets. The monkey menace remains a major challenge, with promises to address it through effective policies and legislation, though no concrete implementation has yet occurred. Joshi emphasized pragmatic, need-based development over grandiose projects, citing his five-decade political experience. Giri highlighted unfinished development work from his previous terms, while Sharma called for systematic development across the district, citing comprehensive plans in education, health, agriculture, livestock, employment, infrastructure, and industrialization. Bhusal advocated for systemic policy and legal reforms to address governance failures. Other parties, including Rastriya Prajatantra Party, CPN Maoist Centre, Rastriya Janamorcha, Ujyalo Nepal, Mongol National Party, Aam Janata Party, National Republic Nepal, Rastriya Janmukti Party, and Nepal Mazdoor Kisan Party, are also conducting detailed election campaigns. The district has 125,466 registered voters, with 76 polling stations and 151 voting centers established.

**Nine Candidates from Two Municipalities in Pyuthan for Upcoming House of Representatives Election**
In Pyuthan District, 14 candidates have filed nominations for the upcoming House of Representatives election on Falgun 21, 2081 (2024). Of these, 9 candidates are from Jhimruk Gaunpalika and Pyuthan Nagarpalika alone, making these two municipalities the most competitive in the single electoral constituency. Among them, 4 candidates are from Jhimruk Gaunpalika: Sunil Thapa (Nepali Congress), Tilak Bahadur Jisi (Rastriya Janmorchha), Govind Giri (Shram Sanskriti Party), and Vimil Pokhrel (Nepali Janata Dal). From Pyuthan Nagarpalika, 5 candidates have filed: Krishna Dhvaj Khadka (CPN-UML), Susant Vaidyek (Rastriya Swatantra Party), Dhaneshwar Pandit (Rastriya Prajatantra Party), Shyam Gahatara (Progressive Democracy Party), and Harka Bahadur Pun (Mongol National Organization). Additional candidates include Prof. Dr. Govindaraj Pokhrel (Nepali Congress), Sita B.K. 'Samjhana' (CPN (Maoist Center)), and Ram Bahadur Thapa (Aama Janata Party). The district has a total of 165,406 voters, with 157 polling stations and 230 polling centers established across two municipalities and seven rural municipalities.

**Election Commission Releases Sample Ballots for Upcoming House of Representatives Election**
The Election Commission of Nepal has publicly released the sample ballots for the upcoming House of Representatives election on Falgun 21, 2026. The samples cover all seven provinces, including separate templates for districts with a single constituency and those with multiple constituencies. The Commission's spokesperson, Narayan Prasad Bhattarai, stated that ballot sizes are determined based on the number of candidates: larger ballots are used in constituencies with more candidates, while smaller ones are used where there are fewer candidates. Single-constituency districts include Salang, Dolpa, Mugu, Jumla, Kalikot, Humla, Jajarkot, and Rukum West in Karnali Province, and two constituencies each in Dailekh and Surkhet. In Sudurpaschim Province, districts such as Bajura, Bajhang, Doti, Darchula, Baitadi, and Dadelhura have one constituency each, while Achham has two, Kanchanpur has three, and Kailali has five. All sample ballots, including those for the proportional representation system, have been officially published.

**Gagan Thapa's Directive: Tell Voters Congress Is the Most New Party**
Nepali Congress President Gagan Thapa instructed party workers to convey the message that the Congress is the 'most new' political party to voters, emphasizing that the party has been rejuvenated following a recent special convention. Speaking at a campaign event in Kathmandu-4 on Saturday, Thapa challenged voters who claim they are voting for a 'new' party by asking them to reflect on the definition of 'old' and 'new.' He argued that since no party is newer than the current Congress—reformed under his leadership before Falgun 6 (February 2026)—the Congress is, in fact, the most new party in Nepal. Thapa stated that a party cannot be considered truly new merely by having a new face, and that one cannot become a new party overnight by simply winning elections. He urged party workers to communicate this message directly to the electorate.

**Beyond Eight General Elections in Asia and the Pacific in 2026: Stability, Transition, and Exceptionalism**
The article analyzes eight general elections in Asia and the Pacific region scheduled for 2026, highlighting their political significance and context. Seven elections were pre-scheduled by constitution or circumstance, while the eighth—Japan’s early parliamentary election—was announced unexpectedly on January 19, 2026, to be held on February 8, 2026. Six of the eight elections determine the head of state or government, including Myanmar, Thailand, Japan, Bangladesh, Nepal, and New Zealand. In Laos and Vietnam—single-party states—parliamentary elections serve as formalities following national party congresses, where top leaders are appointed. In Myanmar, elections (held in three phases: December 28, 2025, and January 11 and 25, 2026) are seen as symbolic, with the military-backed 'Union Solidarity and Development Party' securing over 260 of 330 elected seats in the House of Representatives and over 160 of 224 seats in the House of Nationalities, despite military control since the 2021 coup and ongoing armed conflict. In Bangladesh, the first election since the fall of Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina in August 2024 after student-led protests, will be held on February 12, 2026, with 350 seats contested; the ruling Bangladesh Nationalist Party (BNP), led by Tarique Rahman, is expected to win, facing a fragmented opposition coalition including the Islamist Jamaat-e-Islami and the youth-led 'National Citizen' party. In Nepal, following the resignation of Prime Minister KP Sharma Oli in September 2025 due to youth-led protests, elections on March 5, 2026, will likely restore the traditional left-wing dominance, with the Communist Party of Nepal (Unified Marxist–Leninist) and the Maoist Centre leading a united left front; no single party is expected to win a majority, likely resulting in a coalition government. In Thailand, early elections on February 8, 2026, follow rapid political turnover since 2023, with four prime ministers in two years and a constitutional court ruling that ousted two. The election, contested by the People’s Party, Palang Pracharath, and Move Forward Party, is expected to result in a fragmented parliament, with no single party securing a majority, reflecting ongoing instability. In Japan, early elections were called by Prime Minister Fumio Kishida’s successor, Sanae Takaichi, on January 19, 2026, after her government’s instability and the right-wing shift within the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP), prompting a new centrist coalition between Komeito and opposition parties to counter the rightward trend. In New Zealand, the only 'normal' parliamentary election among the six, scheduled by no later than December 19, 2026, will elect 120 MPs and include a referendum on extending the parliamentary term from three to four years. The election will feature a competitive race between the ruling National Party and the opposition Labour Party, which suffered a major defeat in October 2023. In Laos and Vietnam, elections on February 22 and March 15, 2026, respectively, are formalities following national party congresses—Laos’ 12th and Vietnam’s 14th—where leaders such as Thongloun Sisoulith and To Lam were reappointed, with new development plans for 2026–2030 and long-term visions to 2045 adopted. The article concludes by noting that five of the eight elections are exceptional—due to coups, protests, or early calls—raising questions about political stability, while Laos and Vietnam, despite single-party systems, exhibit greater stability in leadership selection.
Original language: ar
Publish date: January 31, 2026 03:31 AM
Source:[AL Masry Al Youm](https://www.almasryalyoum.com/news/details/4187553)

**Kathmandu-6 Election Race: RSP Aims for Re-election, Congress and UML Seek Comeback, RPP Fields New Candidate**
In the upcoming general election for the House of Representatives, Kathmandu-6 constituency features a competitive political landscape with 20 candidates—15 from political parties and 5 independent candidates. The Rashtriya Swatantra Party (Rastriya Swatantra Party, RSP) is fielding Shishir Khadka, a former elected representative, for a second term, aiming to retain its dominant position. RSP secured the highest votes in both direct and proportional representation in the previous election, with Khadka receiving 14,221 votes. The Nepali Congress has nominated Krishna Subba Baniya, a 61-year-old former district chairperson, who is seeking to reclaim the seat lost in the previous election. Baniya is emphasizing river conservation and urban revitalization as key campaign issues. The Communist Party of Nepal (Unified Marxist–Leninist, CPN-UML) has nominated Aman Kumar Maski, a former provincial minister and central committee member, who is promoting long-term development planning and public service over politics as a profession. The CPN (Maoist Centre) is fielding Himal Sharma, a second-time candidate, who claims to represent the legacy of the late Jhala Nath Khanal and is campaigning under the slogan 'Responsibility of the present, hope for the future.' The Rastriya Prajatantra Party (RPP) has chosen Uddhav Raj Bhatwal, a 36-year-old with postgraduate qualifications, as a new face, promoting a 'victory or nothing' stance and advocating for national sovereignty and democratic institutions. The constituency includes wards from Kathmandu Metropolitan City (26, 27, 28), Tokha Municipality (1, 8, 9, 10, 11), and Tarkeshwar Municipality (1, 2, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11).

**Basukota's Satire on Nepal's Election Rhetoric: 'Hype and Accusations Are Ordinary Here, Not Abroad'**
Nepali Congress leader Gokul Basukota has used satire to critique the current political discourse in Nepal, particularly the overlapping claims by political parties of winning elections and forming single-party governments. In a Facebook post published on January 31, 2026, Basukota wrote, 'When you hear all parties claiming victory and seat calculations, no one seems to be second,' adding, 'Not only have all parties claimed to have won, but each appears to have already formed a single-party government.' He emphasized that the final outcome depends on voters' minds, stating, 'What is in the voter’s heart? The result will reveal itself there.' He contrasted the situation in Nepal with Europe and America, where 'hype, confusion, and accusation-counter-accusation' are common, noting, 'That kind of thing is normal in America and Europe, but here in Nepal, it’s just ordinary.'

**Ahead of March 5 election in Nepal, candidates begin campaigning**
Ahead of the March 5, 2026, general elections in Nepal, political candidates including former Kathmandu mayor Balendra Shah 'Balen' and former prime minister Pushpakamal Dahal 'Prachanda' have begun campaigning across their constituencies. Balen, the 35-year-old prime ministerial candidate of the Rastriya Swatantra Party (RSP), conducted a two-week 'silent campaign' visiting at least 16 constituencies in eastern and western Nepal, including districts in Sudur Paschim and Karnali provinces, without formal speeches. Instead, he engaged crowds by waving, shaking hands, and ringing a bell—his party’s election symbol—drawing spontaneous crowds of all age groups who sought selfies and autographs. His spouse, Sabina Kafley, campaigned door-to-door in his constituency, Jhapa-5. Prachanda, leader of the Nepali Communist Party and former prime minister, emphasized unity among communist parties to defend national sovereignty against 'reactionary forces and foreign elements,' stating he is running at 72 and remains committed to struggle. He highlighted the formation of over 20 political groups into a unified Nepali Communist Party. Nepali Congress president Gagan Thapa, also the party’s prime ministerial candidate, pledged to create domestic employment to reduce youth emigration. The party has fielded 106 new candidates across 165 direct constituencies. Nepali Congress spokesperson Devraj Chalise warned that failing to elect reliable candidates could turn Nepal into a 'laboratory.' Vice President Ram Sahaya Yadav stressed the need for a free, fair, and fearless electoral environment, calling it foundational to Nepal’s federal democratic republic. A total of 18.9 million voters are eligible to elect 165 members directly, with 110 additional members chosen via proportional representation. The elections were triggered after Prime Minister K P Sharma Oli resigned on September 9, 2025, following youth-led Gen Z protests over corruption and a social media ban. Sushila Karki, 73, served as interim prime minister from September 12, 2025, and recommended the dissolution of the House of Representatives, setting the election date.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 31, 2026 12:00 AM
Source:[newsdrum.in](https://www.newsdrum.in/international/ahead-of-march-5-election-in-nepal-candidates-begin-campaigning-11062804)

**Election campaign in Nepal to begin from February 16**
Nepal's Election Commission has announced that the official election campaign period will begin on February 16, 2026, and run until March 2, 2026, ahead of the general election on March 5, 2026. According to Suman Ghimire, deputy spokesperson at the Election Commission, political parties may hold public rallies, mass meetings, and other campaign events during this window, and may publish or broadcast election-related materials through media. However, no campaign activities—including rallies, processions, or assemblies—are permitted before February 16, in compliance with the Election Code of Conduct. Candidates are allowed to conduct door-to-door campaigning even before the official campaign start date. A 48-hour silence period will be enforced from midnight on March 2, during which all campaign activities must cease. The upcoming House of Representatives elections will see 18.9 million eligible voters electing 165 members directly. Of the total 275 members in the Lower House, 110 will be elected through a proportional representation system. The general election was triggered after former Prime Minister K.P. Sharma Oli resigned on September 9, 2025, following violent youth-led protests by the Gen Z group over corruption and a social media ban. Sushila Karki, 73, was appointed interim prime minister on September 12, 2025, and recommended the dissolution of the House of Representatives, leading to the announcement of the election date.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 30, 2026 02:46 PM
Source:[News18](https://www.news18.com/agency-feeds/election-campaign-in-nepal-to-begin-from-february-16-9868604.html)

**Makwanpur-1 Faces New Challenge as Veteran Candidates Meet Fresh Faces in Upcoming Election**
In the Makwanpur-1 constituency, the upcoming House of Representatives election on February 21, 2026, features 23 candidates, including 13 party-backed and 10 independent contenders. The main competition is expected between candidates from the Nepali Congress (NC), Communist Party of Nepal (Unified Marxist–Leninist) (CPN-UML), Rastriya Prajatantra Party (RPP), Nepal Communist Party (NCP), and Rastriya Swatantra Party (RSP). Notably, Mahalakshmi Upadhyay 'Dina' and Deepak Bahadur Singh are contesting their fifth consecutive election in this constituency. Dina has lost all previous elections, while Singh won in 2079 (2022) by a margin of 2,382 votes. CPN-UML’s Vijay Gautam and RSP’s Prakash Gautam are making their first direct electoral challenge. The constituency has seen a significant population increase—from 124,799 in 2074 to 158,435 in 2082—largely due to urbanization in Hetauda Sub-metropolitan City, which hosts 15 wards. The urban population is more educated and politically mobile, increasing the potential for vote shifts. Political analysis indicates that NC and CPN-UML view each other as primary rivals, while downplaying Singh’s threat. NC’s Bhim Sen Mahat anticipates improved performance due to internal party cohesion and stronger urban outreach. CPN-UML’s Hidem Lama expresses confidence in candidate Ramshwar Rana, citing strong party organization and favorable past results. Maoist leader Pralhad Lamichhane believes youth candidates with experience in governance and good governance will gain support, particularly in rural areas. RPP’s Sandip Sapkota Singh claims he will win again, citing consistent public engagement despite not completing a full term in parliament. The election is further shaped by historical trends: Maoists previously won the 2070 Constituent Assembly election and held key local posts in 2079, but have not won a House seat since. The constituency remains politically competitive, with shifting alliances and evolving voter dynamics.

**Nepali Congress emerges as largest party in Upper House**
The Nepali Congress (NC) emerged as the largest party in Nepal's Upper House, the National Assembly, securing nine out of 18 seats in the January 25, 2026, elections, according to the Election Commission of Nepal. The CPN-UML won eight seats, and the Loktantrik Samajwadi Party-Nepal (LSP-N) won one, forming a two-party alliance that captured all 17 contested seats. The Nepali Communist Party (NCP), which previously held eight seats, lost all its representation due to the NC-UML alliance. In the 59-member National Assembly, the Nepali Congress holds 24 seats, the CPN-UML has 10, the NCP has 17, the Janata Samajbadi Party-Nepal (JSP-Nepal) holds two, and one seat each is held by LSP-N and Rastriya Janamorcha. There are also two nominated members and one vacant seat.

**Nepali Congress and Communist Party of Nepal (Marxist-Leninist Unified) Win National Assembly Election**
In the recent National Assembly election held on Sunday, the Nepali Congress won nine seats, and the Communist Party of Nepal (Marxist–Leninist Unified) (PCN-MLU) secured eight seats, according to the Election Commission. The Commission stated in a press release that the Loktantrik Samajwadi Party of Nepal (Social Democratic Party of Nepal) won one seat. The Communist Party of Nepal, formed by the merger of several communist parties including the Communist Party of Nepal (Central Maoist), failed to win any seats, as the Nepali Congress and PCN-MLU formed an alliance. Approximately one-third of the National Assembly seats are vacant every two years and filled through elections. Of the 19 seats vacated on March 4, 2026, elections were held for 17 seats— one candidate was elected unopposed—and President Ram Chandra Poudel, following government recommendation, will appoint one additional member. With 25 seats, the Nepali Congress became the largest party in the 59-member upper house, followed by the Communist Party of Nepal, while the PCN-MLU ranked third.

**Nepal Holds Federal Council Election; Nepali Congress Becomes Largest Party**
On January 25, 2026, the Election Commission of Nepal announced the results of the federal parliamentary council (upper house) election, stating that the Nepali Congress won 9 seats, becoming the largest party in the federal council. The Communist Party of Nepal (Unified Marxist–Leninist) secured 8 seats, the Nepali Social Democratic Party won 1 seat, and the newly formed Communist Party of Nepal—resulting from the merger of the Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist Centre) and other groups—won no seats. The federal council has a total of 59 seats; 18 seats were filled in this election, with the remaining one to be appointed by President Bidya Devi Bhandari. After the election, the Nepali Congress holds 25 seats, making it the largest party in the federal council, followed by the Communist Party of Nepal in second place and the Communist Party of Nepal (Unified Marxist–Leninist) in third.

**Nepali Congress wins 9 seats in upper house**
The Nepali Congress won nine seats in the National Assembly election, followed by the Communist Party of Nepal (Unified Marxist-Leninist) (CPN-UML) with eight seats and the Lokatantrik Samajwadi Party with one seat. The election, held on Sunday from 9 am to 3 pm local time, saw a voter turnout of 95.68%, according to the Election Commission (EC). The process concluded peacefully nationwide. The Nepali Congress and CPN-UML had previously reached a pre-poll agreement ahead of the vote for the 18 vacant seats in the upper house. **Nepali Congress Surpasses Nepal Communist Party in National Assembly Election Amid Coalition Gains**
In the January 25, 2026, National Assembly election in Nepal, the Nepali Congress emerged as the largest party with 25 members, surpassing the previous leader, the Nepal Communist Party (NCP), which saw its membership drop from 25 to 17 after 8 of its members lost their seats. The election results followed a coalition agreement between the Nepali Congress, Communist Party of Nepal (Unified Marxist–Leninist) (CPN-UML), and the Loktantrik Samajwadi Party (LSP), under which candidates from each party won in the 18 contested seats. CPN-UML secured 8 seats, LSP won 1 seat (Mahant Thakur), and Nepali Congress won 9. The NCP's loss of seats is attributed to its decision to run independently after failed coalition talks. The CPN-UML and NCP Maoist Centre (17) and CPN (Unified Socialist) (8) had previously merged to form the NCP, which had 25 members. The CPN-UML's 8 members will also leave office in February 2026. The LSP will retain 1 seat, and the Janata Samajwadi Party Nepal will reduce from 3 to 2 members. The National Assembly has 59 members, with 3 members being appointed by the President on government recommendation. The election had a voter turnout of 95.68%, with 550 Provincial Assembly members and 1,506 local leaders serving as voters. The term of office for National Assembly members is 6 years, with one-third elected every two years. NCP leader Agniprasad Sapkota stated that the election was not a direct public vote but a 'fixed' process involving elected representatives, and that the party would review the results. The results indicate a significant shift in the political landscape, with the coalition parties gaining dominance over the previously dominant NCP.

**Ravindra Mishra’s Third Attempt in Kathmandu-1: A High-Stakes Political Battle**
Ravindra Mishra, a senior leader of the Rastriya Prajatantra Party (RPP), is making his third attempt to win a seat in the House of Representatives from Kathmandu-1, following two previous defeats. In the 2022 election, he lost to Nepali Congress’s Prakashman Singh by 125 votes, and in the 2017 election, he was defeated by a margin of 818 votes. This time, Singh is not contesting. Mishra remains optimistic, stating on Facebook: 'Victory in the third attempt is certain, and I will contribute to saving and building the nation, just as King Prithvi Narayan Shah achieved victory in his third attempt.' Kathmandu-1 has 30 candidates in the race, including prominent contenders such as Praval Thapa Kshetri (Nepali Congress), Mohanraj Regmi (CPN-UML), Menuka Bhandari (CPN (Unified Marxist–Leninist)), and Ranju Nyawapane (Rastriya Swatantra Party). Praval Thapa emphasized education, health, and a 'Mission Employment' campaign, aiming to achieve a median income country within 10 years. Mohanraj Regmi highlighted his commitment to pure and transformative politics, while Menuka Bhandari stated that her campaign agenda is being developed directly with citizens through community consultations. Ranju Nyawapane, a former candidate from Kathmandu-5, has switched to Kathmandu-1 under Rastriya Swatantra Party and is now competing against Mishra from a different party. Other candidates include independent and smaller party representatives such as Ramila Jyakhwe (Nepal Mazdoor Kisan Party), Rajkumar Limbu (Miteri Party), and Kamal Suwedi (Janadesh Party). The constituency has 14 independent candidates, including Kishor Khatri, Sangeet Bam, Kamal Koirala, and others. The election is highly competitive, with all candidates claiming victory, but Nepali Congress is seen as the frontrunner due to its previous win in the area.

**World News | Major Political Parties Move Toward Alliance for Upper House Election | LatestLY**
Four major political parties in Nepal—the Nepali Congress, the CPN-UML, the Nepali Communist Party (formed from a coalition of communist groups including the former CPN-Maoist Centre), and a coalition of Madhes-based parties—are negotiating a strategic alliance for the upcoming National Assembly election on January 25, 2026. The election will fill 18 seats vacated by members completing their six-year terms, as part of the chamber’s biennial retirement cycle. According to preliminary discussions, the seat allocation is tentatively set at seven for the Nepali Congress, six for the CPN-UML, four for the Nepali Communist Party, and one for the Janata Samajbadi Party Nepal. Senior leaders from the Nepali Congress, including Vice President Purna Bahadur Khadka, met with CPN-UML Chairman KP Sharma Oli and General Secretary Shankar Pokharel to finalize arrangements. The UML is expected to have the highest number of retiring members (eight), followed by the Nepali Communist Party (seven). The Nepali Congress, despite being the second-largest party in the upper house, has no members retiring in March. All candidates must file nominations by January 7, 2026. Congress spokesperson Prakash Sharan Mahat stated, 'If we do not tie up, it will be difficult to win even a single seat.' The alliance discussions were initiated after an understanding was reached between Nepali Congress President Sher Bahadur Deuba and UML chair Oli, with subsequent coordination involving Nepali Communist Party coordinator Pushpa Kamal Dahal. Of the 19 seats to be filled, 18 are elected by an electoral college composed of provincial assembly members (weighted at 53) and local government leaders (weighted at 19), while one is nominated by the President on government recommendation. The National Assembly is a permanent chamber of Parliament, established under the Constitution. The lower house was dissolved on September 12, 2025, following the Gen Z movement.
